msDesc.head: GILBERT, PRISCIAN, GILES OF CORBEIL, SIMON OF FAVERSHAM; S. XIV in.

physDesc.p: Structurally two volumes, but probably always together, as part of a larger book in which II was bound before I.

supportDesc.extent:
68 leaves (ii + 67) 340 235
255–65 170
The edges retrimmed, affecting marginalia, and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: 1–212, 312(4, 11 canc.), 48, 512, 66(lacks 4–5) / 78(lacks 8). At least one quire is missing after 5.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on five bands; formerly chained from the usual position and also from near the head of the front board. Fols. i-ii, 66–7 are paper binding leaves, the outermost from the same printed book as in MS 68. On f. 58v are the marks of two foredge straps or catches and, near the foot, of the large iron chain-staple.

history.provenance: At the foot of f. 40v, in early pencil, is ‘Hornecastr 4’, of f. 42v ‘Graham. 5.’, of f. 45 ‘Barthon 4’, of 46 (in ink) a quaestio‘... etiam opponit Donatus. Barton. 3’, of f. 49 ‘Graham secundario’, of 50v ‘Hornecastr 3’. Hornecastr may be William de Horncastr’ (BRUO 966), in charge of expenditure for scholars of the founder’s kin at Merton College in 1340 and 1347. Barton may then be William de Barton (BRUO 123–4), fellow in 1356, until 1361. According to Dr J. Catto, these notes suggest that the manuscript was used by a master to lecture and organize disputations in-house for Mertonian bachelors proceeding to the status of Master.
At the foot of f. 57v is ‘prec’ xv s.’ At the foot of f. 11 is ‘Wylkyn be war of Jankyn’, probably only a pen trial.

On f. 58v, among the pen trials, is ‘Vinum bibat mane cerebrumque reformat inane
Quem profudit heri crapula multa meri. Quod Wyttham’, and ‘O quam iocundum quam amenus foret dominari
S mors non posset dominantibus insidiari
Sed quia mors semper comes est et causa doloris
Non est honor sed onus assumere nomen honoris. Quod W[erased]’. Possibly Thomas Wytham (BRUO 2129), fellow in 1419, no longer in 1422, d. by 1470.
At the head of f. 1 is the James no. ‘103’ (wrongly), s. xvii in., canc.
Inside the front board is a table of contents, s. xvii, and ‘Q. 2. 4. Art:’, canc. and replaced with ‘O. 2. 4 (CCLXXXVIII)’ in red; the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

msItem.title: Commentary on GILBERT OF POITIERS, Liber Sex Principiorum
msItem.incipit: Aristoteles in quinto metaphisice dicit quod unum quod dicitur tantum dicitur perfectum
Liber sex principiorum cuius expositionem intendimus
msItem.explicit: quod generatur per actionem ignis generatur simpliciter et ignis.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber sex principiorum cum literali expositore super eodem.
msItem.note: Apparently the unique copy. A commentary with a similar incipit (‘Prout uult Aristoteles quinto metaphysicae’) is recorded by Bale, Scriptores i. 405, and by Tanner, p. 113 n. b, as by the early 14th-cent. Luke Bosden OCarm, otherwise unknown: Sharpe, Handlist, p. 368.

msItem.title: Commentary on PRISCIAN, Institutiones 17–18

msItem.title: Commentary on GILES OF CORBEIL, De Vrinis

msItem.note: Text ed. L. Choulant, Aegidii Corboliensis Carmina Medica (Leipzig, 1826), pp. 1–18; Wickersheimer 196–7; WIC 4432. Comm. unpr.; eTK 1483B; Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 143–4.

There is a good deal of pencilled annotation throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with pencil and crayon in 2 cols of 71 lines. Blocks of text and gloss alternate, the text in larger script on alternate lines.

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 1–54v an English gothic rotunda hand of university type, in the commentary much influenced by anglicana. fols. 55–7v are probably in the same hand, now writing just as formally in the commentary.

decoDesc.decoNote: None: unfilled spaces for initials and rubrics.
